_items.body:
Is the processing necessary to comply with obligations under an existing contract the organisation has with the individual?

Has an individual asked you to take specific steps before entering into a contract?

Take this example:

When you purchase something online, a controller processes your address so that the goods can be delivered. This is necessary to perform the contract.

On the other hand, profiling your interests and preferences based on the items you bought is not necessary for the performance of the contract and does not comply with this legal basis.
_items.title: Contract

_items.body:
Is the processing necessary for you to comply with legal obligation?

Take this example:

As with every organisation, the ODI is required to process personal data to comply with its legal obligation to provide employee salary details to HMRC. Therefore this is a lawful basis for processing data.
_items.title: Legal obligation

_items.body:
Is the processing necessary to protect an individual's life?

Take this example:

An ODI employee falls ill whilst at work and is taken to hospital. Staff records on the company asset register reveal that he/she has a pre-existing medical condition. These records are handed over to the hospital to protect his/her life. Therefore this is a lawful basis for processing data.
_items.title: Vital interests

_items.body:
In the ODI we often work with public sector organisations so it's useful to consider what advice we could provide.

Is the processing necessary for you to perform a task in the public interest? 

Is it necessary for you to perform your official functions (providing it has a clear lawful basis)?

Take this example

Companies House registers company information and makes it available to the public. This means anyone can freely look up a company's profile, accessing the names, nationalities and dates of birth of any directors. This is a lawful basis for processing data.
_items.title: Public tasks

_items.body:
Is the processing necessary for your legitimate interests ie to conduct business?

Is it necessary for the legitimate interests of a third party? 

Take this example:

With a number of external stakeholders involved in our projects like R&D, we keep contact information up to date on our Customer Relationship Manager (CRM). This means we can send project outputs as and when required. This is a lawful basis for processing data.
_items.title: Legitimate interests

_items.body:
Has the individual given clear consent for you to process personal data about them for a specific purpose?

Take this example:

In last year's R&D peer-to-peer accommodation project we interviewed members of the public about renting accommodation on Airbnb. All interviewees were required to sign a consent form for this. Therefore this is a lawful basis for processing data.
_items.title: Consent

title: Where does it apply?
body:
The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

The GDPR also applies to the processing of personal data about individuals who are in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, if it offers goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required).

Processing personal data covers the following, irrespective of how the data is collected:

collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destruction.

title: What exactly is the GDPR?
body:
In its simplest form, the General Data Protection Regulation aims to 'harmonise' data privacy laws within the EU, modernising the legislation put into place by the Data Protection Act of 1998. In a rapidly evolving data-led landscape, the GDPR introduces a robust compliancy framework focusing on the increased protection of fundamental rights and freedom of individuals.

But as the greatest shake up to privacy laws in some 20 years, the GDPR not only brings benefits to the individual consumer, but also promises to be a catalyst for data-led innovation.

Here at the Open Data Institute we are excited about taking a lead on this. Revised compliancy laws bring opportunities to build trust with clients, manage our data more efficiently and grow business initiatives.

title: How increased rights can support innovation
displayTitle: How increased rights can support innovation
body:
As we have seen, the GDPR will strengthen existing individual rights over personal data as well as introducing new ones. Of these, data portability is something we talk widely about here at the ODI and there is much discussion over its potential in driving innovation and creating new products and services.

The re-use of data across other services may play a significant role in addressing the lack of competition in markets, for example, where users could be given wider choice of switching between providers. 

One example of sites which facilitate data of this type is Money Supermarket. Can you think of any other examples?

Want to know more about data portability? Read the blog written by Gillian and Jack here.

_items.body:
Previously referred to as sensitive data, special categories of personal data require a higher level of protection as its processing could create serious risks to the fundamental rights and freedoms of a person. These include:

  • racial or ethnic origin
  • political opinions
  • religious or philosophical beliefs
  • trade union membership
  • genetic and biometric data (new in the GDPR)
  • physical or mental health or conditions
  • sex life or sexual orientation
_items.title: Special categories of personal data

_items.body:
Data relating to criminal convictions and offences, or related security measures may only be carried out when:

  • it is under the control of an official authority.
  • the processing is authorised by European Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for people's rights and freedoms.
_items.title: Criminal convictions data

_items.body: Data about children must be treated carefully as they may be less aware of the risks involved. When consent is required for the use of data about someone under 16 years old, that consent must be given by a holder of parental responsibility for that child
_items.title: Data about children

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: What are my rights?
body:
As well as the right to a privacy notice, there are eight additional rights which a person can choose to exercise. Under the GDPR you can ask questions about the way in which data about you is being processed. 

As you read, consider what this means for you as an individual as well as an ODI staff member. Which rights open up the most potential for data-led innovation?

_items.body:
Are you processing data about me?

Where is this data being processed?

And for what purpose?

Organisations have one month from a subject access request to provide a copy of the personal data in an electronic format where possible.
_items.title: A right to access

_items.body:
The data about me is wrong. Can you correct it?

Personal data can be corrected if inaccurate or incomplete. This also applies to any copies shared with others.
_items.title: A right to rectification

_items.body:
Can you erase the personal data about me?

Going forward, can you stop sharing this data?

Can you stop third parties processing data about me?

When an individual withdraws consent, data must be erased.

Data must also be erased if it is no longer relevant to the original purpose for processing or no lawful basis exists for the data to be held and processed.
_items.title: A right to be forgotten

_items.body:
Can you ‘block’ or suppress the processing of personal data about me?

This can be exercised when:

  • the accuracy of the personal data is contested
  • the individual has objected to the processing (only in the case of performance of a public task or legitimate interest)
  • the processing is unlawful
  • the data is needed for future reference but should no longer be processed
_items.title: A right to restrict processing

_items.body:
Can I see a copy of the personal data I have given you, or that you have automatically gathered from me?

Can you transmit my data directly to another organisation? 

An organisation must provide this in a commonly-used, machine-readable format.
_items.title: A right to data portability

_items.body:
Can I withdraw my consent?

If the lawful basis for processing data is based on consent the individual has the right to withdraw at any time. 

The process should be as simple as opting to consent in the first place.
_items.title: A right to withdraw consent (where applicable)

_items.body:
Can you stop processing data about me?

The right only applies in certain circumstances.

If one of the following is met, the right can be exercised:

  • When data is used for direct marketing 
  • When data is used for research or statistical purposes (unless necessary for public interest ie health research)
  • When the data is processed in the public interest/ in legitimate interests.
_items.title: A right to object

_items.body:
Are decisions being made about personal data via automated processing?

Automated processing can be carried out if the decision is:

  • Necessary for the entry into/performance of a contract
  • Authorised in law
  • Based on the individual's explicit consent

Individuals must be informed as well as be permitted to request human intervention or challenge a decision.
_items.title: A right to not be subject solely to automated decision making

title: Privacy by design
body: Philip works with us here at the ODI as Head of Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning. With the introduction of the GDPR, his role will now be affected by the requirements of 'privacy by design'. 'Privacy by design' promotes privacy and data protection compliance from the start of each project and should be considered at all stages of development.

_items.body:
Where data processing is likely to result in a higher risk to individuals (eg a major project involving the use of personal data) a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is required under the GDPR. 

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

In line with our principles, we promise to publish our DPIAs openly. We will also guide other organisations to do the same with the help of our Data Ethics Canvas (see below).
_items.title: Data Protection Impact Assessment

_items.body:
In addition to acting as a decision-making tool, the Data Ethics Canvas encourages us to look at the broader ethical issues involved in working with personal data.

The canvas can be used alongside a DPIA to help ensure ethical data-led innovation.

title: The scope of the GDPR: personal data
body:
Under the GDPR, personal data refers to any data relating to an identifiable person. This means anything which can result in the direct or indirect identification of an individual. Remember, people can also be identified by physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social factors.

In isolation, the examples listed on the left may not necessarily make a person identifiable – take the common name, John Smith. We could be talking about a number of different men. But combine this with other data like John's address and his date of birth and suddenly we are talking about John Smith, 30 years old from Cherry Tree Lane, Islington, London.

title: The General Data Protection Regulation
body:
On 25 May 2018 the General Data Protection Regulation came into effect, amending data protection regulations across the European Union.

In this learning module we will look at what this new legislation means for us and delve into some of the benefits which will accompany it. 

  • What exactly is the GDPR?
  • How does it affect us here at the Open Data Institute? 
  • How does it affect our individual rights?
  • How can we follow codes of best practice to ensure we keep personal data secure?

title: Component title
body: Can you remember a time when you were a child and you accidentally broke something. Did you own up? Or was the fear or being told off too great?

_items.body:
At the Open Data Institute we are open by definition. If you think you have breached the GDPR please act quickly and inform your line manager. The quicker you act, the easier we can work together to provide solutions.

The GDPR introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority. This includes both accidental and deliberate breaches.
_items.title: What should I do in a breach?

_items.body:
Modification to or unauthorised destruction of data or documents containing personal data

Always check which files can or cannot be altered or deleted.

Loss or theft of staff equipment or devices

Keep tabs on any devices you are responsible for (eg  mobile phone, laptop, USB stick etc) both at work and in public spaces.

Unauthorised use

Be aware of who has access to company data or IT systems.

Incorrect or unauthorised sharing

Ensure you know how and who data can be shared with.

Human error

Mistakes can happen, even with client-facing interfaces eg an employee posting a client's photo on Twitter without their consent. Keep this in mind when using social media.
_items.title: What is a breach?

title: How does it affect us here at the ODI?
displayTitle: How does it affect us here at the ODI?
body:
All of our staff here at the ODI must apply the GDPR when processing any type of personal data. This could be HR and employee records, member information and customer lists. Even if you are in a department or role that does not deal with large quantities of personal data, it is likely that at some point you will find yourself handling it.

Can you recall the last time you handled personal data? Maybe you compiled a guest list, sent out information for an event, or sent a group email to your stakeholders.

title: Privacy best practice
body:
When was the last time you bought something online? Before you submitted your personal details did you check or uncheck the privacy boxes? 

Privacy notices are one of the most visible aspects that demonstrate compliance with the GDPR. This is why, at the ODI, we make sure our website, tools, newsletters etc all come with a privacy notice. 

Under the GDPR, a privacy notice must disclose:

  • what data is being collected
  • what the data is being used for and how an individual can exercise their rights over the data

This information must be presented to the individual as near to the point of data collection as possible. 

In addition to fines being imposed for non-compliance, they can also be imposed where a privacy notice is deemed unclear or misleading. These can be up to a maximum of £17 million!

title: The GDPR and our principles
body:
Being open about how personal data is used, and how privacy is protected, helps to build trust in organisations collecting and using personal data. Greater trust means less friction when developing new ideas and services. It facilitates more connections and network effects. It helps consumers feel empowered, and leads to more informed choices about services that involve collection of personal data. Openness makes things better.

Our principles encourage organisations to commit to being ‘open’ in a number of ways. ‘Open’ means both sharing information (publicly online and directly to people), and being open to feedback from people about how things could be improved.

Click on each pin to look at the type of questions we should be asking ourselves.

title: Summary
body:
In this module we have looked at what the General Data Protection Regulation is and the effects it will have on both an individual and organisational level. We have also assessed the codes of best practice which we can all follow to maintain data security on a daily basis.

With a more robust compliancy framework, the GDPR aims to increase the protection of our fundamental rights but also promises to be a catalyst for data-led innovation. Here at the Open Data Institute we are excited about the increased opportunities to build trust with our clients, manage our data more efficiently and continue to inspire organisations to innovate with data.

Do you have any feedback on this module? Do you have further questions about the GDPR? Please get in touch with us at training@theodi.org

title: Our Data Protection Officer
body:
Under the GDPR, public authorities are required to appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO). Although this is not a requirement for an organisation our size, we're aligning ourselves with larger organisations because of who we are. As the ODI we think we should measure ourselves against a high standard so we're taking on extra activities, including the appointment of our own DPO. 

Our Data Protection Officer is Leigh Dodds.

Leigh monitors internal compliance and acts as a contact point both internally and externally. Leigh can offer you:

  • guidance on data protection obligations
  • advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs)
  • insight into how we're conforming to the GDPR here at the ODI

You can also seek advice from the rest of the policy team, as well as Debbie who will be able to share knowledge.

title: Establishing a lawful basis for processing data
displayTitle: Establishing a lawful basis for processing data
body:
The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner. There are six lawful bases outlined in the GDPR. At least one must apply. Without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process personal data. 

Want to know more? Visit the Information Commissioner's Office.

_items.body:
Will the data be used to help deliver a service?

Will the data be linked with other information about the person?

Will the data be shared with other organisations or be used for research purposes?

Click to find out more under our following principle:

'Organisations should be open with people about what personal data they are collecting'

_items.body:

Click to find out more under our following principle:

'Organisations should be open with people about the way personal data is secured'

_items.body:
How long do I need to keep this data for?

Is it necessary for me to keep the data for contractual reasons ie financial information or employee records?
_items.title: Archive

_items.body:
What data is being shared; with whom; for what purpose; under what conditions; and for what return (eg financial return, or because it’s a necessary part of providing a person with a service)?

Click to find out more under our following principle:

'Organisations should be open with people about the way personal data is shared'
_items.title: Share

_items.body:
How will the organisation use different types of data? Will it be used to deliver a service, conduct analysis or simply maintain records?

Click to find out more under our following principles:

'Organisations should be open with people about how they use personal data'

'Organisations should help people understand and influence how their data is collected and used'

_items.body:
How long am I allowed to keep this data?

How can I ensure it is destroyed securely?
